Hello
question
is it possible to transition between views (not activities or fragment)
yes
<https://guides.codepath.com/android/Shared-Element-Activity-Transition>
I know it's said Activity
But for view is the same
Basically you define a shared id for the element you want to transition
And you go from there
<http://stackoverflow.com/questions/28386397/shared-element-transitions-between-views-not-activities-or-fragments>

text: i can’t as then i cant get a bitmap
you are on the right path setting a size (I assume that’s what into() does)
i can use this listener, but then i need a call back, which is not suitable as i need to iterate thru a list of files to process
yes, you can only manipulate bitmaps
android doesn’t have functionality to manipulate any other image type so all supported image types are read into memory as bitmaps
mmm u are right, i might use the output and then center crop it without doing it all inline
thanks for the idea

Hey guys. I was trying to create a generic way to show loadings/generic error dialogs in my app. In order to do this I've created a BaseActivity and a BaseView. and there i have my 2 dependencies to create the dialogs: 
`@Inject protected LoaderManager loaderManager ` and `@Inject protected ErrorDialog errorDialog;`
But by doing this I need to inject both my BaseView and my "normal" views ... I don't really enjoy this approach. What you guys think? Or any suggestion for a new approach to achieve this ?
`protected abstract void injectThis();`
Those 2 injects trigger me
Only because I need dependencies on my BaseView and on my child views
Does this class extend another class?
Yes, FrameLayout in case of BaseView and AppCompatActivity in case of BaseActivity
ahh I see

you can get more lightweight than a compoundview
a compound view is basically a fragment.. so ¯\_(ツ)_/¯

attachments.title: ANDROID DEVELOPMENT LIKE A PRO
attachments.text: The Android Sdk has changed much since its first version. Every new version comes with many new APIs. However, there is no perfect API, some do too much under the hood, others couple your classes to the context, others have more lifecycle events than you have years in your life.;The talk will show how to make your app scalable, your code clean, your performance optimized and your UI neat. The talk will show in a pragmatic way the pros and cons of using certain Android APIs, strategies and libraries. It will touch on Fragments, Loaders, AsyncTasks, OOP patterns (mvp vs mvvm vs viper) and styling.;This talk is a compendium of my experience in large code bases since I started to work in Android in 2009.
attachments.fallback: Vimeo Video: ANDROID DEVELOPMENT LIKE A PRO

Hi guys, I want to expose the 'onSharedPreferenceChange' callbacks from my PreferenceHelper class via RxJava
I'm currently using Observable.create() with a class that implement ObservableOnSubscribe
Is it better to use PublishSubject ?
it is best to use `PublishRelay`
or maybe even `BehaviorRelay`
Ok thanks ! I'll check that out
I have a hard time finding RxJava2 tutorial and docs.
Is the RxJava wiki still up to date, even for RxJava2 ?
(And is publishrelay only available in Rxrelay ? or is it bundled in rxjava ?)
it's in RxRelay
Thanks :slightly_smiling_face:
It depend on RxJava 1.2.4 :confused:
no
it works with rxjava2 ?
`compile 'com.jakewharton.rxrelay2:rxrelay:2.0.0'`
oh I see
I was looking at the 1.2.0 ! My bad
What is the difference between BehaviorRelay and BehaviorSubject (in RxJava2) ?
BehaviorSubject stops sending stuff if it ever receives `onError()`.
Oh okay thanks for the quick response !
It seems to work quite well !
And it's much simpler than with Observable.create
Although, since the relay can't send errors and completes, is there a 'special' observer to work with when subscribing ? (which doesn't implement them)
or do I just make a defaultObserver with two empty methods

attachments.title: Handling Runtime Changes | Android Developers
attachments.text: Some device configurations can change during runtime (such as screen orientation, keyboard availability, and language). When such a change occurs, Android restarts the running Activity (onDestroy() is called, followed by onCreate()). The restart behavior…

text: Note: Using this attribute should be avoided and used only as a last resort. Please read Handling Runtime Changes for more information about how to properly handle a restart due to a configuration change.
<https://developer.android.com/guide/topics/manifest/activity-element.html#config>

attachments.title: | Android Developers

...I don't think I ever had nearly as much trouble with RealmObjects not supporting types outside of the supported types as this issue makes it seems like a problem.
sure, `RealmList<Integer>` is a pain, but you can just make it into a `String` with join separator `,`
sure, `RealmList<String>` is a pain, but you can also hack it into a single `String` column with a bit funkier joining strategy
maybe my issue is that I've only ever used `Date` and never bothered with integrating `ThreeTenABP` because I was just fine with the Calendar API and `DateUtils` from apache lang
